title: How to Make Beef Stew

steps.headline: Trim the beef to bite sized pieces.
steps.description: Get out a 3 to 4 pound (1.3 to1.8 kg) beef chuck roast and use a sharp knife to cut off visible fat. Cut the trimmed roast into cubes that are about 1 in (2.5 cm) in size. Ensure the cubes are the same size so the beef cooks evenly.

steps.headline: Sear half of the beef cubes over medium-high heat for 4 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of the vegetable oil into a large pot or Dutch oven. Heat the oil over meidum-high so it begins to shimmer. Then add half of the beef cubes so they're in a single layer. Sprinkle the meat with several pinches of salt and pepper. Avoid stirring the beef cubes while they sear or they won't develop a crust.

steps.headline: Stir and sear the cubes for 4 to 5 more minutes.
steps.description: Use a spatula or spoon to stir the beef. Try to turn the pieces over so another side of the cubes sear. Stir the beef cubes once more while they cook so most of the beef cubes develop a brown crust. Put the seared meat on a platter and set it aside while you sear the remaining beef cubes. Set all of the beef cubes aside on a plate once you've finished searing both batches. If the cubes stick to the bottom of the pot, you can add another 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of vegetable oil.

steps.headline: Sauté the onions and celery for 8 to 10 minutes over medium heat.
steps.description: Dice 2 onions and 3 stalks of celery before you place them in the hot skillet. Stir and cook the vegetables until the onions become soft and translucent. It's important to stir the vegetables frequently so they don't stick to the bottom of the pan.

steps.headline: Stir in the garlic and cook it for 30 seconds.
steps.description: Mince 2 cloves of garlic and stir it into the sautéed onions and celery. Stir and cook the garlic just until it becomes fragrant. Avoid cooking the garlic for more than 30 seconds because it can burn easily.

steps.headline: Add the tomato paste, salt, and half of the Worcestershire sauce.
steps.description: Stir in 2 tablespoons (32.5 g) of tomato paste, 1 teaspoon (5.5 g) of salt, and 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of the Worcestershire sauce. The vegetables should be coated with the tomato paste.

steps.headline: Coat the sautéed vegetables with flour.
steps.description: Sprinkle 3 tablespoons (23 g) of all-purpose flour over the vegetables in the pot. Use a spoon to stir the mixture until the vegetables absorb the flour. The flour will make the vegetables look mushy or soft. Coating the vegetables with flour will thicken the stew as it simmers.

steps.headline: Pour the wine or beer into the pot and scrape the bottom of the pot.
steps.description: To deglaze the pot and build flavor, pour 1 cup (240 ml) of red wine or amber beer into it. Turn the burner to medium-high so the liquid begins to bubble vigorously. Stir the bottom of the pot thoroughly so the sticky bits are combined with the liquid.

steps.headline: Return the beef to the pot along with the stock, bay, and thyme.
steps.description: Put the browned cubes of beef back into the pot and pour in any juices that accumulated. Stir in 4 cups (950 ml) of chicken stock, 1 bay leaf and 3 sprigs of fresh thyme or 2 teaspoons (1.5 g) of dried thyme. Stir so the sautéed vegetables are combined with the broth and seasonings. If you don't have chicken stock, substitute beef broth, vegetable stock, or water.

steps.headline: Cover and simmer the stew for 1 1/2 hours.
steps.description: Keep the burner at medium-high heat until the liquid comes starts to bubble. Then turn the burner down to low so it simmers. Put the lid on the pot and keep the stew at a gentle simmer. Stir the stew occasionally to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the pot. If you prefer, put the covered pot of stew in a 300 °F (149 °C) oven and cook it for 1 1/2 hours.

steps.headline: Add the potatoes and carrots.
steps.description: Dice 3 carrots and cut 1 ⁄2 pounds (680 g) of potatoes into 1 in (2.5 cm) cubes. Stir them into the stew and put the lid back on the pot. You can use your favorite type of potato such as Russet, Yukon Gold, or Red Bliss.

steps.headline: Cover and cook the stew for 45 to 60 more minutes over low heat.
steps.description: Stir the stew occasionally as it simmers. The meat should become completely tender and the potatoes should be soft. If the meat isn't tender, simmer the stew for 15 more minutes and check it again.

steps.headline: Stir in the peas and remaining Worcestershire sauce.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and stir in 1 cup (150 g) of frozen peas. Add the remaining 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of Worcestershire sauce and remove the bay leaf. Taste the stew and add salt and pepper according to your taste. Store refrigerated stew in an airtight container for up to 1 week or freeze it for up to 3 months.

tyn: Large pot with lid or Dutch oven
text: Sautéing the Beef and Vegetables Trim the beef to bite sized pieces. Get out a 3 to 4 pound (1.3 to1.8 kg) beef chuck roast and use a sharp knife to cut off visible fat. Cut the trimmed roast into cubes that are about 1 in (2.5 cm) in size. Ensure the cubes are the same size so the beef cooks evenly. Sear half of the beef cubes over medium-high heat for 4 to 5 minutes. Pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of the vegetable oil into a large pot or Dutch oven. Heat the oil over meidum-high so it begins to shimmer. Then add half of the beef cubes so they're in a single layer. Sprinkle the meat with several pinches of salt and pepper. Avoid stirring the beef cubes while they sear or they won't develop a crust. Stir and sear the cubes for 4 to 5 more minutes. Use a spatula or spoon to stir the beef. Try to turn the pieces over so another side of the cubes sear. Stir the beef cubes once more while they cook so most of the beef cubes develop a brown crust. Put the seared meat on a platter and set it aside while you sear the remaining beef cubes. Set all of the beef cubes aside on a plate once you've finished searing both batches. If the cubes stick to the bottom of the pot, you can add another 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of vegetable oil. Sauté the onions and celery for 8 to 10 minutes over medium heat. Dice 2 onions and 3 stalks of celery before you place them in the hot skillet. Stir and cook the vegetables until the onions become soft and translucent. It's important to stir the vegetables frequently so they don't stick to the bottom of the pan. Stir in the garlic and cook it for 30 seconds. Mince 2 cloves of garlic and stir it into the sautéed onions and celery. Stir and cook the garlic just until it becomes fragrant. Avoid cooking the garlic for more than 30 seconds because it can burn easily. Assembling the Stew Add the tomato paste, salt, and half of the Worcestershire sauce. Stir in 2 tablespoons (32.5 g) of tomato paste, 1 teaspoon (5.5 g) of salt, and 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of the Worcestershire sauce. The vegetables should be coated with the tomato paste. Coat the sautéed vegetables with flour. Sprinkle 3 tablespoons (23 g) of all-purpose flour over the vegetables in the pot. Use a spoon to stir the mixture until the vegetables absorb the flour. The flour will make the vegetables look mushy or soft. Coating the vegetables with flour will thicken the stew as it simmers. Pour the wine or beer into the pot and scrape the bottom of the pot. To deglaze the pot and build flavor, pour 1 cup (240 ml) of red wine or amber beer into it. Turn the burner to medium-high so the liquid begins to bubble vigorously. Stir the bottom of the pot thoroughly so the sticky bits are combined with the liquid. Return the beef to the pot along with the stock, bay, and thyme. Put the browned cubes of beef back into the pot and pour in any juices that accumulated. Stir in 4 cups (950 ml) of chicken stock, 1 bay leaf and 3 sprigs of fresh thyme or 2 teaspoons (1.5 g) of dried thyme. Stir so the sautéed vegetables are combined with the broth and seasonings. If you don't have chicken stock, substitute beef broth, vegetable stock, or water. Simmering the Stew Cover and simmer the stew for 1 1/2 hours. Keep the burner at medium-high heat until the liquid comes starts to bubble. Then turn the burner down to low so it simmers. Put the lid on the pot and keep the stew at a gentle simmer. Stir the stew occasionally to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the pot. If you prefer, put the covered pot of stew in a 300 °F (149 °C) oven and cook it for 1 1/2 hours. Add the potatoes and carrots. Dice 3 carrots and cut 1 ⁄2 pounds (680 g) of potatoes into 1 in (2.5 cm) cubes. Stir them into the stew and put the lid back on the pot. You can use your favorite type of potato such as Russet, Yukon Gold, or Red Bliss. Cover and cook the stew for 45 to 60 more minutes over low heat. Stir the stew occasionally as it simmers. The meat should become completely tender and the potatoes should be soft. If the meat isn't tender, simmer the stew for 15 more minutes and check it again. Stir in the peas and remaining Worcestershire sauce. Turn off the burner and stir in 1 cup (150 g) of frozen peas. Add the remaining 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of Worcestershire sauce and remove the bay leaf. Taste the stew and add salt and pepper according to your taste. Store refrigerated stew in an airtight container for up to 1 week or freeze it for up to 3 months.
sentences: Sautéing the Beef and Vegetables Trim the beef to bite sized pieces.
Get out a 3 to 4 pound (1.3 to1.8 kg) beef chuck roast and use a sharp knife to cut off visible fat.
Cut the trimmed roast into cubes that are about 1 in (2.5 cm) in size.
Ensure the cubes are the same size so the beef cooks evenly.
Sear half of the beef cubes over medium-high heat for 4 to 5 minutes.
Pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of the vegetable oil into a large pot or Dutch oven.
Heat the oil over meidum-high so it begins to shimmer.
Then add half of the beef cubes so they're in a single layer.
Sprinkle the meat with several pinches of salt and pepper.
Avoid stirring the beef cubes while they sear or they won't develop a crust.
Stir and sear the cubes for 4 to 5 more minutes.
Use a spatula or spoon to stir the beef.
Try to turn the pieces over so another side of the cubes sear.
Stir the beef cubes once more while they cook so most of the beef cubes develop a brown crust.
Put the seared meat on a platter and set it aside while you sear the remaining beef cubes.
Set all of the beef cubes aside on a plate once you've finished searing both batches.
If the cubes stick to the bottom of the pot, you can add another 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of vegetable oil.
Sauté the onions and celery for 8 to 10 minutes over medium heat.
Dice 2 onions and 3 stalks of celery before you place them in the hot skillet.
Stir and cook the vegetables until the onions become soft and translucent.
It's important to stir the vegetables frequently so they don't stick to the bottom of the pan.
Stir in the garlic and cook it for 30 seconds.
Mince 2 cloves of garlic and stir it into the sautéed onions and celery.
Stir and cook the garlic just until it becomes fragrant.
Avoid cooking the garlic for more than 30 seconds because it can burn easily.
Assembling the Stew Add the tomato paste, salt, and half of the Worcestershire sauce.
Stir in 2 tablespoons (32.5 g) of tomato paste, 1 teaspoon (5.5 g) of salt, and 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of the Worcestershire sauce.
The vegetables should be coated with the tomato paste.
Coat the sautéed vegetables with flour.
Sprinkle 3 tablespoons (23 g) of all-purpose flour over the vegetables in the pot.
Use a spoon to stir the mixture until the vegetables absorb the flour.
The flour will make the vegetables look mushy or soft.
Coating the vegetables with flour will thicken the stew as it simmers.
Pour the wine or beer into the pot and scrape the bottom of the pot.
To deglaze the pot and build flavor, pour 1 cup (240 ml) of red wine or amber beer into it.
Turn the burner to medium-high so the liquid begins to bubble vigorously.
Stir the bottom of the pot thoroughly so the sticky bits are combined with the liquid.
Return the beef to the pot along with the stock, bay, and thyme.
Put the browned cubes of beef back into the pot and pour in any juices that accumulated.
Stir in 4 cups (950 ml) of chicken stock, 1 bay leaf and 3 sprigs of fresh thyme or 2 teaspoons (1.5 g) of dried thyme.
Stir so the sautéed vegetables are combined with the broth and seasonings.
If you don't have chicken stock, substitute beef broth, vegetable stock, or water.
Simmering the Stew Cover and simmer the stew for 1 1/2 hours.
Keep the burner at medium-high heat until the liquid comes starts to bubble.
Then turn the burner down to low so it simmers.
Put the lid on the pot and keep the stew at a gentle simmer.
Stir the stew occasionally to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the pot.
If you prefer, put the covered pot of stew in a 300 °F (149 °C) oven and cook it for 1 1/2 hours.
Add the potatoes and carrots.
Dice 3 carrots and cut 1 ⁄2 pounds (680 g) of potatoes into 1 in (2.5 cm) cubes.
Stir them into the stew and put the lid back on the pot.
You can use your favorite type of potato such as Russet, Yukon Gold, or Red Bliss.
Cover and cook the stew for 45 to 60 more minutes over low heat.
Stir the stew occasionally as it simmers.
The meat should become completely tender and the potatoes should be soft.
If the meat isn't tender, simmer the stew for 15 more minutes and check it again.
Stir in the peas and remaining Worcestershire sauce.
Turn off the burner and stir in 1 cup (150 g) of frozen peas.
Add the remaining 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of Worcestershire sauce and remove the bay leaf.
Taste the stew and add salt and pepper according to your taste.
Store refrigerated stew in an airtight container for up to 1 week or freeze it for up to 3 months.
